The effect of organic modifiers on Ag/Al2O3 catalysts for the sequential hydrogenation of 1-octyne vs 1-octene Revana Chanerika a Mzamo L. Shozi a Mirko Prato b Holger B. Friedrich a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa School of Chemistry and Physics University of KwaZulu-Natal Durban South Africa aSchool of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, South Africa b Materials Characterisation Facility, Instituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Italy Materials Characterisation Facility Instituto Italiano di Tecnologia Italy bMaterials Characterisation Facility, Instituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. The selective hydrogenation of 1-octyne (in 1-octene) to 1-octene was carried out over a 5Ag/Al2O3 catalyst coated at one monolayer (ML) coverage with 20 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][NTf2]) as the first model system, followed by coating with 15 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([BMIM][PF6]), 15 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([BMIM][BF4]), 15 wt% tetrabutylammonium nitrate ([N4444][NO3]) and the equivalent organic modifier, 1-ethylimidazole [EIM] (10 wt%). The initial uncoated catalyst gave high octyne conversions (99%) with a selectivity to 1-octene at 30% initially, reaching 70% within 24 h on-stream. In an attempt to improve the selectivity and catalyst stability with time, modifying the catalyst with [EIM] gave 1-octene selectivities of 50% over 36 h time-on-stream with an average 1-octene gain of 10 wt%. The conversion of 1-octyne decreased significantly from 99% over the uncoated catalyst to 30% over the modified version as a result of diffusion limitations. However, coating with different ionic liquids ([BMIM][NTf2], [BMIM][PF6], [BMIM][BF4] and [N4444][NO3]) gave increased 1-octene selectivities reaching up to 82% over the 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] catalyst. The stability of most SCILLs was maintained for a period exceeding 10 h after which deactivation of the active catalytic sites by either poisoning or metal sintering led to a decline in activity. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Silver Ionic liquids Selective hydrogenation 1-octyne Monolayer 1 Introduction Much effort has been devoted to designing catalysts with high catalytic performance for many industries [1]. A necessity in industrial practice has been to remove alkynes (and dienes) from alkene streams, which are considered catalyst poisons [2]. They decrease the catalyst activity by reducing the cycle length, increasing the pressure drop in the reactor, blocking catalyst pore entrances or increasing carbon deposition [3]. Thus, the selective hydrogenation of alkynes to alkenes is important. Terminally hydrogenated alkynes can give alpha-alkenes which have high industrial value [4]. Their low thermal stability allows for functionalisation (alpha alcohols, oxygenates, etc.) without extreme reaction conditions or the use of copious amounts of potentially toxic solvent. Silver has a low affinity towards hydrogen due to the filled d-band, as opposed to metals such as nickel, palladium, and platinum. Thus, the weak interaction of hydrogen with its extended metal surfaces such as found in single crystals and polycrystalline surfaces provides minimal dissociative chemisorption [5]. This inhibits the production of unwanted over-hydrogenated products due to limited surface saturation by hydrogen. This is in contrast to sub-surface hydrogen formation that results from extensive coverage of hydrogen on the catalyst surface and promotes the formation of unwanted side products. Efforts to combine the advantages of homogeneous systems with heterogeneous ones include a combination of catalysts and ionic liquids. As a result, higher reaction rates, more selective reactions, better catalyst stability and good recovery of the catalyst were achieved [6]. The incorporation of ionic liquids (ILs) in transition metal catalysts has introduced simpler work-up procedures and at the same time prevented time consuming and laborious purification steps [7]. The only drawbacks associated with ILs are their costs and mass transfer limitations due to the IL viscosity [8]. There are two main strategies of combining catalysts with ILs. These are Supported Catalysts with an Ionic Liquid Layer (SCILLs) and Supported Ionic Liquid Phase (SILP) catalysts. ILs can tune the physicochemical properties of SILPs and SCILLs [9]. SCILLs are traditional transition metal heterogeneous catalysts coated with an ionic liquid layer. The interaction of ionic liquids with active sites has been identified by Arras and co-workers [10–12] and may be interpreted as a ligand effect created by the IL similar to the influence of a second metal in bimetallic catalysts [10]. The ionic liquid also functions as a semi-permeable coating layer controlling the effective concentrations of reactants and intermediates as well as the electronic state of the active sites [13–15]. It is also suggested that the IL prevents metal particles from oxidising [16]. Herrmann et al. [17] studied 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium dicyanamide ([BMIM][DCA]) and 1,3-dimethylimidazolium methylphosphite ([DMIM][MeHPO3]) coatings over a PdAg/Al2O3 catalyst in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. An acetylene conversion of 89% was noted over the bare catalyst and coating with [BMIM][DCA] gave suppressed conversions of 79% at 70 °C with a selectivity to ethene of 80%. Over the [DMIM][MeHPO3]-based SCILL, less acetylene was converted (45%). Ethylene selectivities of 80% and 83% over the [BMIM][DCA]- and [DMIM][MeHPO3]-based SCILLs, respectively, were achieved with alkane formation being strongly inhibited. The decline in conversion was attributed to the diminished solubility of hydrogen in the IL film. SILP catalysis concerns immobilising a catalyst into an IL, followed by impregnation onto a carrier [18]. This type of catalysis is a good alternative to traditional heterogenisation methods for homogeneous catalysts, however, drawbacks such as catalyst leaching and difficult product separation steps are experienced [19]. Thus, we chose to investigate Ag-SCILLs for selectively removing octyne from octene feedstocks. While there are no reports on the terminal activation of 1-octyne using Ag-based SCILLs, the combination of ionic liquids with Ag/Al2O3 was expected to increase the 1-octene content in a mixed octyne and octene feed compared to what was found over the uncoated catalyst. This study further targeted mild reaction temperatures, important considering that supported imidazolium-based ionic liquids decompose at temperatures greater than 100 °C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The 5 wt% Ag on Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by the deposition precipitation method using silver nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%) and gamma alumina (Merck, 99%). The pH of the mixture was adjusted to 10 with 25% ammonia solution. The uncoated catalyst was dried over 6–8 h using a rotary evaporator at 70 °C under vacuum and then oven dried overnight at 110 °C prior to calcining at 500 °C for 12 h. The catalyst was then activated under pure hydrogen at 160 °C for 12 h at 40 mL/min. Modification of the solid catalyst with 20 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][NTf2]), 15 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([BMIM][PF6]), 15 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([BMIM][BF4]), 15 wt% tetrabutylammonium nitrate ([N4444][NO3]) and 10 wt% 1-ethylimidazole ([EIM]), was carried out by suspending the ionic liquid or EIM in an acetone solution and then adding the mixture to a round bottom flask containing the desired amount of solid catalyst. The solvent was removed at 60 °C under reduced pressure using a rotary evaporator until a dry powder was obtained. The SCILLs was further dried under reduced pressure overnight prior to catalytic testing. The catalysts were characterised by Isopropylamine-Temperature Programmed Desorption (IPA-TPD), Brunauer Emmett and Teller (BET) analyses, High Resolution-Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM), Backscattered Electron-Scanning Electron Microscopy (BSE-SEM), H2-chemisorption, Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES), Thermal Gravimetric Analysis-Differential Scanning Calorimetry (TGA-DSC), Infrared (IR) Spectroscopy, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) and X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). Full details can be found in the Supplementary Information. 2.2 Competitive hydrogenation of an octyne/octene mixture All catalytic work was carried out in the liquid phase using a continuous, plug flow fixed-bed reactor with a downflow operation. All catalysts (2 mL loading) were diluted with 24 grit carborundum in a 1:1 ratio and packed into the hotspot of a 316 stainless steel reactor tube with an inner diameter of 15 mm and length of 325 mm. Glass wool was packed on either side of the catalyst bed and the reactor tube to prevent particulate matter from entering the product stream. Leak tests were conducted prior to the commencement of each reaction by holding a high pressure of nitrogen (50 bar) for a period of time. To ensure an isothermal environment, the reactor was covered by an insulating jacket. The internal and external reactor temperatures were controlled by means of thermocouples connected to a thermocouple control box. The competitive liquid feed consisted of 2 wt% octyne and 10 wt% octene in hexane which was fed through 1/8th inch 316 stainless steel reactor tubing using a LabAlliance series II isocratic pump. The liquid product stream was collected in a 500 mL stainless steel catchpot. The flow of hydrogen and nitrogen was controlled by Brooks mass flow controllers. The excess gas was expelled through a Ritter Drum Type TGI-model 5 wet gas flow meter. A Tescom pressure regulator was used to maintain the set reactor pressure before the sampling catchpot. Prior to each reaction, all SCILLs were dried under N2 atmosphere at 90 °C for 1 h. The hydrogen gas was continuously fed at a set gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) together with the liquid feed at a specific liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV). The IL weight loading and space velocity was studied over the 5Ag-[BMIM][NTf2] and [BMIM][PF6] catalysts to investigate the effects of IL coverage and reactant residence time, respectively. One monolayer (ML) is defined as a closed pair of ions covering the surface of the catalyst. The product mixture was quantified by a Perkin Elmer Clarus 580 Auto System Gas chromatograph equipped with a Flame Ionisation Detector (FID) and a PONA column. All results were obtained in at least duplicate, with mass balances between 97 and 103% and carbon balances between 101 and 106%. Eqs. (1)–(6) were used in the calculations for this work. The gain of 1-octene is defined as the product (1-octene) resulting from the conversion of 1-octyne from the competitive feed, with no conversion of 1-octene. All ionic liquids were deposited at concentrations corresponding to one monolayer coverage to acquire a closed layer of ion pairs on the surface of the catalyst that was expected to offer selectivity advantages. An organic modified (EIM modified) catalyst was further prepared (in the same way as the SCILLs) to determine if ionic liquids offer advantages over simple organic modifiers. 3.1 Characterisation 3.1.1 SEM-EDS line scans SEM-EDS analysis was performed on the bare 5Ag/Al2O3 catalyst and a selected SCILL (5Ag-15%[BMIM][BF4]) to gain information on the spatial dispersion and distribution of silver on alumina. Fig. 1 (a) shows good metal dispersion over the surface of alumina and is complimented by the line scan analysis (Fig. 1(b)) showing constant Ag peak intensity across the scanned area. Usually, the metal peak intensity in a line scan increases proportionately to the number of bright spots detected. The absence of this confirmed even metal distribution of silver prior to coating. In the SCILL, a similar pattern to the fresh IL-free catalyst was noted in terms of silver distribution on the surface of alumina. The presence of the ionic liquid ([BMIM][BF4]) loaded at 15 wt% (theoretically one monolayer) is confirmed by Fig. 1(d) where the fluorine trace confirms the IL present on the surface. The line scan in Fig. 1(d) further provides an indication of the interaction of the ionic liquid and the supported metal. Peak intensities for both Ag and F are consistent showing uniform coverage of the ionic liquid over the catalyst surface. Furthermore, these intensities support a low IL loading on the surface, at a theoretical single monolayer. As the metal peak intensity increases, the intensity of F increases proportionally. This indicates good interaction between the ionic liquid and metal. SEM-EDS analysis was also carried out over 5Ag-10%[EIM] and 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] (Fig. S1, Supplementary Information), however, these ionic liquids only contain nitrogen and this makes confirmation of the presence of the coating difficult by this technique. Hence, other characterisation methods were used to confirm the coating of all ionic liquids on the surfaces of the catalysts (discussed later). 3.1.2 XRD The XRD diffractograms in Fig. 2 show the uncoated catalyst [20] and the ionic liquid modified catalysts. The uncoated catalyst was reduced under 100% H2 prior to coating. There are no distinct changes in peak intensities among all IL coated catalysts and there is no evidence of the oxidised species (AgO or Ag2O), rather only metallic silver is seen. The Ag0 peaks at 2θ: 38.12°, 44.75°, 65.46°, 78.37, 82.05° correspond to the (111), (200), (220), (311) and (331) lattice planes, respectively, matching the JCPDS file 04–0783. All Ag peaks of the SCILLs appear sharper and more intense than those of the unmodified catalyst. This may suggest that the silver is a little less dispersed on the Ag-SCILLs, with a possibility of random distribution of agglomerates of silver in the coated catalysts. It is possible that coating with the different ionic liquids possibly weakened the metal-support interaction. This also shows that the ionic liquid remains physisorbed on the surface of the catalyst, allowing changes to the crystallites to take place. The XRD patterns further reveal that the catalysts do not require an additional reduction step after coating with an ionic liquid and show that the IL prevents the oxidation of silver in air, unless IL leaching occurs. Furthermore, no oxidation of silver takes place during the preparation of the SCILLs. 3.1.3 XPS XPS was used to investigate the electronic structure of selected fresh and used catalysts: 5Ag/Al2O3, 5Ag-10%[EIM] and 5Ag-15%[BMIM][BF4]. With this technique, ionic liquid-metal and organic modifier-metal interactions were established including their modes of adsorption near the surface of the catalyst. Important XP spectra, Ag 3d, N 1s and C 1s are represented in Figs. 3 , 4 for the bare and coated catalysts. The Ag 3d XP spectra in Fig. 3 revealed the presence of metallic silver by two main peaks, one at ∼368 eV and the second at ∼374 eV for the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spin orbitals, respectively [21]. Peak asymmetry in all fresh catalysts indicated the presence of two chemical states, the other possibly due to some oxidised silver species usually reported at ∼368 eV [21]. Peaks appeared more symmetric in the used catalysts, suggesting only one chemical environment of silver. Fig. 4(a) shows the N 1s XP spectra for the fresh and used EIM coated and IL coated catalysts. The N 1 s peaks for the fresh EIM/IL coated catalysts have two features, with the imidazolium nitrogen peak at ∼401 eV and the other peak at ∼399 eV being assigned to an amine [22], since in 1-ethylimidazole, there are two types of nitrogen environments, pyridinium and pyrrolidinium in a five-membered ring [23]. In the used EIM coated catalyst, the intensity of the imidazolium component is now lower than the corresponding amine indicating some decomposition of the imidazolium ring. The signal-to-noise ratio is also seen to be low which further implies a low content of nitrogen in the sample. A third nitrogen peak is seen for the EIM coated catalyst at ∼397 eV due to the presence of adsorbed metal nitrides lending further evidence towards the decomposition of the ring [24]. The absence of this peak at ∼397 eV in the used IL catalyst implies good IL distribution over the catalyst surface where imidazole-support interactions are less dominant and do not aid the decomposition of the ring. Furthermore, the intensity of the imidazolium feature in the used IL catalyst almost matches that of the fresh implying at most a slight change to the structure of the IL during the reaction. Fig. 4(b) shows the C 1s XP spectra for the fresh and used coated catalysts. Due to overlapping environments as a result of close binding energies, two peaks are evident, aliphatic carbons (Calkyl) at ∼285 eV and carbons bound directly to nitrogen (Chetero) at ∼286 eV [25]. The spectral weight within the binding energy range of 283–290 eV for all catalysts result in four carbon signals from the BMIM+ cation: aliphatic carbons (CC/CH bonds, C1), aliphatic CN with carbon bound to only one nitrogen (C2), aromatic CN with carbon bound to only one nitrogen (C = CN in the imidazolium ring, C3), and aromatic CN with carbon bound to two nitrogens (in the imidazolium ring, C4) [26]. In the used coated catalysts, the C3 signal is reduced indicating a reduction in the C = C = N species, again implying decomposition and partial removal of the imidazolium ring during the reaction. However, this was seen to occur to a greater extent over the EIM coated catalyst compared to the IL coated catalyst due to support interactions as previously explained. Additional Al 2p, O 1s, F 1s, B 1s and survey XP spectra are presented in the Supplementary Information. In Fig. S2 (Supplementary Information), the main Al 2p signal at ∼ 74 eV in all catalysts is attributed to the Al-O bond present in γ-Al2O3 [27]. The smaller component at higher binding energy is also due to alumina and results from spin-orbit coupling which causes the energy level to split in two. Interestingly, in all used catalysts, there is a weak third peak appearing at lower binding energy (∼68 eV) and is a result of an interaction with an impurity in the octyne feed (1-bromohexane). The O 1s XP spectra in Fig. S3 (Supplementary Information) shows two signals with the main component at ∼531 eV due to alumina and the second at ∼532 eV due to adsorbed moisture [25]. The main Al 2p and O 1s signals in Figs. S2, S3 for the used uncoated and EIM coated catalysts show a shift to higher binding energy, and this suggests possible surface charging occurring due to insufficient EIM coverage [23]. Fig. S4 (Supplementary Information) shows a single F 1s peak at ∼685 eV and a B 1s peak at ∼192 eV. There is no change in the intensities of these signals in the used catalysts compared to the fresh indicating no significant loss or leaching of the IL during the reaction. At a take-off angle of 0° with respect to the sample normal direction, the configuration of ions lying close to the surface of the catalyst can be identified [28]. Importantly, since the N 1s: F 1s ratio of 0.37 lies close to 0.33 (nominal) [29], a checkerboard or side-side arrangement of ions lying close to the surface can be identified as a monolayer [29]. Survey spectra for all investigated catalysts are shown in Fig. S5 (Supplementary Information). The survey scans show all expected peaks and are dominated by oxygen, aluminium, carbon, nitrogen and silver peaks where relevant. 3.2 Catalytic testing over Ag-SCILLs 3.2.1 Preliminary catalytic studies with 1-octyne and 1-octene Non-competitive experiments were carried out to probe the influence of the organic modified and SCILL systems on 1-octyne and 1-octene hydrogenation. SCILLs were chosen based on donor strength of the anion and compared with the uncoated and organic modified catalysts. Non-competitive 1-octyne hydrogenation experiments (Fig. 5 (a)) showed that all catalysts gave 100% conversion. Different selectivity profiles of the organic modified and SCILL systems illustrated the importance of the ionic liquids in minimising octane and internal octene formation. Full 1-octyne conversions suggested effective adsorption occurring in the presence of the ionic liquid under the set reaction conditions. Generally, alkynes have higher heats of adsorption compared to alkenes and, hence, the absence of the competing 1-octene leads to unhindered adsorption of 1-octyne on the surface of the catalyst. Both octane and internal octene isomers were formed in greater quantity over the bare [20] and 5Ag-10%[EIM] catalysts and the IL coating effectively reduced their selectivity over the SCILLs. This is attributed to the bulkiness of the ionic liquid. The thin uniform layer of the ionic liquid in conjunction with higher heats of 1-octyne adsorption prevent the readsorption and diffusion of products and also limit secondary reactions from taking place on the support. In the non-competitive 1-octene hydrogenation (Fig. 5(b)), at almost constant conversion, there were no major differences in the selectivity to octane and internal octenes when comparing the SCILLs and uncoated catalyst. It would seem that the ionic liquid does not play a role in blocking the active sites sufficiently to reduce octane and octene isomer formation. However, comparing the two sets of non-competitive experiments, i.e. the octyne only and octene only results, it is evident that the IL indeed hinders the adsorption of octene to a greater extent than octyne. Thus, in the octyne only study, all catalysts showed 100% conversion with little by-product formation. In the octene only experiment, there was limited surface saturation of octene due to the IL, hence octene conversion is only ∼32%. For the low conversions observed, besides the lower heats of adsorption shown by alkenes and the competition between 1-octene and the IL for adsorption on surface sites, it is possible that the IL preferentially adorbs over flat sites (preferred site for alkene adsorption) further hindering octene adsorption. From the two non-competitive studies, there is now clarity on the manner in which adsorption occurs with 1-octyne in the presence of 1-octene. In order to limit isomerisation and over hydrogenation, there needs to be another competing component that will adsorb more strongly than octene and this together with the influence of the IL tunes the selectivity. Hence, the mode of adsorption of the IL and its bulkiness, as well as IL coordination are factors determining the amount of 1-octene that can be “gained” in a mixed octyne/octene feed. 3.2.2 Hydrogenation of an octyne/octene mixture over Ag-SCILLs The competitive hydrogenation of a 2% octyne and 10% octene mixture in hexane over the uncoated 5Ag/Al2O3 dominantly gave 1-octene over 26 h at full conversion, after which the catalyst significantly deactivated due to the build-up of carbonaceous material over the catalyst surface (Fig. S6, Supplementary Information) [20]. Initially, the reduced and exposed active silver sites are available for the competitive adsorption of 1-octyne and 1-octene and thus the over-hydrogenation reaction occurs and a high quantity of octane is formed. As layers of carbon begin to deposit on the surface, the 1-octene formed is desorbed from the surface at the instant it is formed due to diffusion limitations associated to both hydrogen and 1-octyne adsorption as well as carbon deposition. To prevent the initial over-hydrogenation reaction and also limit the carbon deposited, ionic liquids impregnated as monolayers over 5Ag/Al2O3 were probed to see if these maintain high selectivity to 1-octene and give longer catalyst stability (past 26 h). Enhanced selectivities have been shown in several selective hydrogenation studies using various catalysts, substrates and ionic liquids [17,30,31]. The selectivity enhancement occurs very specifically for certain ions, with a strong dependence on the anion [10,11]. Soft anionic behavior of S- and P-based ionic liquids for the competitive hydrogenation of octyne in octene The effect of weight loading of [BMIM][NTf2] on 5Ag/Al2O3 From theoretical monolayer calculations according to Barth et al. [32], a closed monolayer of ion pairs that can form over the unmodified catalyst surface corresponds to a loading of 20 wt% for [BMIM][NTf2]. There are obvious mass transfer limitations associated with ionic liquids which are deposited as layers to form SCILL systems. These limitations include low diffusivity of hydrogen and liquid reactants through the IL layer compared to organic solvents [10,33,34]. For this reason, suppressed conversions are expected when comparing unmodified systems to coated ones. Ideally, monolayer coverages by ILs would be preferred to maintain high alkene selectivities. Below these loadings, side reactions result, such as those which produce green oil and those which form over-hydrogenation products. It was further proven that for all SCILL systems, one IL monolayer is sufficient and preferred since a higher loading of IL induces a diffusion barrier and therefore a lower activity [35]. To study the effect on octene selectivity, loadings up to one monolayer coverage were investigated. Fig. 6 shows a comparison of these systems with that of the unmodified catalyst at isoconversion of 18 ± 0.4% across IL loadings of 5, 10 and 20 wt% corresponding to submonolayer (5 and 10 wt% IL) and monolayer coverages (20 wt% IL). Conversions are significantly affected by mass transfer limitations. In addition, being a soft electron donating atom, sulfur strongly coordinates to the Ag metal hindering reactant accessibility. At submonolayer coverages of 5 and 10 wt% [BMIM][NTf2] on 5Ag/Al2O3, there is possible island formation of ion pairs over the active phase exposing bare active sites that reduce mass transfer limitations. The amount of C16 dimers formed at lower IL loadings (5 and 10 wt%) was higher than at one monolayer coverage, Fig. 6. Since the dimerisation is an acid catalysed reaction, this implies more exposure of the alumina. Also, TGA analyses (Fig. S7, Supplementary Information) of the fresh and used submonolayer 5Ag-[BMIM][NTf2] catalysts (5 and 10 wt%) show the presence of soft aliphatic carbons (200–400 °C region), whilst hard (graphite-like) hydrocarbons were represented by a weight loss in the 400–600 °C region [36]. The contribution of these hydrocarbons resulted in a greater weight loss in the temperature range where ionic liquids decompose (17.5 wt% and 20 wt% at 5 wt% and 10 wt% IL loading, respectively, Table 1 ). There are two main reasons for the observed catalytic results. Firstly, sulfur is a well-known poison, especially for Ag, and this effect dominates. The sulfur-containing anion of the IL is able to block sites that are capable of accumulating half-hydrogenated intermediates and polymerising them to form soft and hard carbon deposits. In this case, “others” (Fig. 6) were significantly reduced. It has been documented that an interaction with a nucleophilic additive weakens the metal affinity to an alkene to a greater extent than to an alkyne and promotes its desorption rather than its reaction [37–39]. Secondly, the closed monolayer of alternating cations and anions in a checkerboard (according to the XPS) rather than an “on-top” planar formation (energetically favoured for large, less basic anions) [40–42] over the catalyst surface prevents exposure and access to the active silver sites by the reactants. Hence, from a site blocking mechanism induced by the IL, 1-octene once formed from the hydrogenation of 1-octyne, is quickly expelled by the IL. This prevents its readsorption onto the catalyst surface for internal isomerisation, over-hydrogenation and polymerisation reactions, as observed with [BMIM][NTf2] on 5Ag/Al2O3. As a result, there was a constant 1-octene gain across the three loadings of IL. Time-on-stream with Ag/Al2O3 coated with 15%[BMIM][PF6] Since a monolayer of IL gave the best results; however, a sulfur poisoning effect was suspected, an IL with a PF6 counter ion was explored. At one monolayer coverage of [BMIM][PF6], corresponding to an IL loading of 15 wt%, a constant 1-octene gain is evident across the 72 h time-on-stream with a selectivity of 60% to 1-octene (Fig. 7 ). During the first 26 h of reaction, 1-octyne conversions reach 18% but decrease to 5% over the next 36 h and further to 2% at the end of the time-on-stream. Phosphorus is a harder donor compared to sulfur, its coordination to silver is less strong and, hence, improved 1-octyne conversion would be expected. However, this was not seen and the active sites are being poisoned slowly by phosphorus. Additionally, a decline in activity may also be attributed to the leaching of 0.80 wt% of silver during the course of the reaction (as determined by ICP-OES results) which is caused by the presence of the IL and implies a stronger Ag-IL interaction, since the loss of silver is negligible between the fresh and used uncoated catalysts (Table S1, Supplementary Information). The selectivity to 1-octene is affected by the densely packed layer of anions and cations contributing to the monolayer. The [PF6]− anion is smaller in size compared to [NTf2]−. Once the anions and cations pack on the surface of the catalyst, the adsorption of the less strongly adsorbing 1-octene is blocked, hence, selectivity to 1-octene is stable at 60% under the reaction conditions. Its readsorption is further prevented due to the steric inaccessibility of the active sites. In addition, TGA analyses showed that the ionic liquid remains intact through the duration of the reaction as the used catalysts show a weight loss corresponding to the amount of IL initially loaded (Fig. S8, Supplementary Information). This also contributes to the stable 1-octene selectivity seen over time. If the IL leached, conversions would steadily increase and selectivities to octane and internal octenes would eventually match those of the unmodified catalyst. The non-polar hexane solvent can also form an immiscible barrier around the IL-liquid feed interface, preventing its leaching [23]. From the reported “physical solvent effect” or “ligand-type effect” induced by the IL, the catalytic performance shows the possibility of both effects in that both reactant solubility (limited in the ionic liquid) and ion coordination causes suppressed 1-octyne conversions. According to Sobota et al. [43], access to the active sites can be hindered due to the steric bulk and coordinating ability of the IL to the active metal. This in turn affects the binding modes of the liquid reactants through the IL-solid catalyst interface onto the active metal phase. In this case, 1-octyne adsorption occurs more easily than 1-octene forcing its expulsion from the surface once formed, hence its selectivity is improved. 3.2.2.1.3 Effect of LHSV over the 15%[BMIM][PF6] SCILL The effect of changing LHSV is shown in Fig. 8 . The conversion increases from 15% at a LHSV of 18 h−1 to 23% at 9 h−1. The increasing 1-octene gain and selectivity as LHSV decreases, shows that the increased contact time allows for the incoming reactant to better adsorb onto the active surface sites with a higher probability of hydrogenation to form 1-octene. The longer substrate-catalyst surface interaction also promotes the competitive adsorption of 1-octene onto the surface where higher amounts of octane and cis-2-octene content (20% at 9 h−1 vs 10% at 18 h−1) are formed. This suggests that some of the 1-octene formed readsorbs onto acidic sites of the catalyst surface instead of diffusing out of the ionic liquid layer. The decreased content of heavies with decreasing LHSV indicates better interaction between hydrogen and the substrates which prevents their accumulation on the catalyst surface to form aliphatic or graphite-like coke. Influence of hard anionic character of B- and N-based ILs Time-on-stream studies The anion, [BF4], was chosen to investigate the influence of boron on Ag as a soft Lewis acid. It has been reported that the anion is responsible for the ligand-like effect, with the cation controlling the solvent-like characteristics of the IL [44,45]. The different electron donating atoms that make up the anions are capable of either strong or weak coordination to the metal [46,47]. Fluorine is a weak Lewis base and will therefore not coordinate to the metal as strongly as phosphorus or sulfur (soft electron donating ability) [47,48]. If boron is considered to coordinate to the Ag, then the interaction would be weak, as boron is a harder donor compared to sulfur or phosphorus. With the weaker anion-metal adsorption, active silver sites are available for the competitive adsorption of, firstly, 1-octyne and 1-octene, followed by hydrogen. Hydrogen is small and will therefore occupy sites in between adsorbed reactant molecules and can sometimes share common Ag surface atoms [15,37]. The current reaction conditions show, from Fig. 9 , that the rate of hydrogenation exceeds the rate of oligomerisation, since a constant selectivity to 1-octene (as well as a gain) is noted over the 30 h time-on-stream. When the rate of hydrogenation is high, there is enough surface hydrogen available to minimise the half-hydrogenated intermediates formed on the surface coupling to form heavies, hence a low formation of “others” is noted. Since the [BF4]− anion is smaller than [PF6]−, it would form a densely packed mesh as a monolayer over the catalyst surface which can affect the access of reactants, reduce reactant coverage and block weakly adsorbing reactants [15]. The close arrangement of ion pairs in a side-side/checkerboard orientation can cause the cation-anion interaction to increase, where the basic anion could abstract the acidic proton from the imidazolium ring [48–51], causing its decomposition. This was not seen in the TGA analysis, where the decomposition of the original amount of IL loaded (Fig. S8, Supplementary Information) was seen. Additional diffusion barriers created by the viscosity of the ionic liquid can lead to accumulation of both reactant and product, reducing conversions with time as observed in Fig. 9. Also, the presence of the ionic liquids in both catalysts seems to cause some leaching of silver with losses of 0.80 wt% and 1.05 wt% for the 5Ag-15%[BMIM][PF6] and 5Ag-15%[BMIM][BF4] catalysts, respectively, (Table S1, Supplementary Information) further contributing to the decline in activity over both catalysts. Considering that the trends caused by the IL seen thus far follow the HSAB theory, i.e. soft acids coordinate to soft bases, the anion, [NO3]−, should weakly interact with the metal and increase the activity [47]. From Fig. 10 , the observed trends regarding the conversion of 1-octyne are similar to those seen in Fig. 9, however, the noted difference is that 1-octyne conversions are substantially improved over the 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] SCILL at 6 h on stream, reaching 48%. Work done by Arras et al.[10]. showed that the use of ammonium-based ILs gave a higher uptake of hydrogen and this is also seen in this work (Table 2 ) and discussed later. Furthermore, the low viscosity of this particular ionic liquid allows permeation of the adsorbing reactant and desorption of the products, rather than allowing their accumulation within the ionic liquid layer. The decline in activity with this particular IL occurs faster compared to the [PF6]−- and [BF4]−-anion-containing ILs and may be due to the generation of a char residue (cyano groups which are prone to polymerisation) and also some leaching of 0.99 wt% of silver (Table S1, Supplementary Information) [52]. The generation of this residue was implied by TGA experiments which also showed the loss of a small amount of ionic liquid after the reaction (Fig. S8, Supplementary Information). The rapid hydrogenation of 1-octyne initially may be aided by a relatively low diffusion limited catalyst surface (i.e. low amount of carbon laydown in addition to the IL), explaining the initial high catalytic activity (48% conversion during 6 h). With access to the active metal sites becoming difficult and the readsorption of 1-octene being prevented by the additional carbonaceous layer, a constant selectivity (80%) and 1-octene gain is noted throughout the 26 h time-on-stream study. In this case, the over-hydrogenation reaction to produce octane thus is inhibited and so is the isomerisation of 1-octene to produce internal octene isomers. Experimental evidence of factors controlling the performance and selectivity of the Ag-SCILLs Miscibility and chemisorption studies The current study has shown definite anionic interactions from the time-on-stream studies and hence ligand-like effects associated with the chosen ionic liquids. However, reagent miscibility within each ionic liquid still needed to be determined. Hexane, 1-octene and 1-octyne solubility tests are shown in Fig. S9 (Supplementary Information). Only 1-octyne was soluble in the organic modifier, EIM, whilst remaining immiscible in all other ionic liquids. 1-Octene and hexane were immiscible in the chosen ionic liquids as well as in EIM, confirming that the adsorption of 1-octene onto the active sites is difficult because initially its permeability is hindered in the ionic liquid-solvent interface. This result confirms a solvent effect, apart from ligand effects and IL surface arrangements previously explained, where the selectivity was primarily towards 1-octene and there was always a gain of 1-octene recorded over all SCILLs in their individual time-on-stream reactions. Although 1-octyne solubility remains low in all modified catalysts, its higher adsorption coefficient compared to 1-octene allows a certain degree of permeability through the ionic liquid-solvent interface to reach the active sites for hydrogenation, giving the aforementioned activity over each SCILL. Hydrogen chemisorption was carried out to assess H2 uptake and metal dispersion on each SCILL and the organic modified catalyst. From Table 2, hydrogen uptakes and metal dispersion values were much lower over all imidazolium-containing catalysts compared to the uncoated catalyst, while a slight increase in these values was noted over the organic modified and ammonium-containing catalysts only. Dispersion and H2 uptake values were similar over the EIM- and [N4444][NO3]-based catalysts, and similar over the [BMIM][NTf2]- and [BMIM][PF6]-based catalysts. This suggests that the hard nitrogen donating atoms and soft donating (S- and P-) atoms within the ILs may give similar catalytic performance. These results compliment the previously observed higher catalytic performance of the [N4444][NO3] Ag-SCILL among the series of tested SCILLs because its IL is the least viscous, apart from it having the highest uptake of hydrogen and metal dispersion. Compared to the unmodified catalyst, the amount of carbon deposition over the active sites on the SCILLs were minimised as the surface remained low in 1-octyne and hydrogen concentrations, implying that for any adsorbed 1-octyne molecule there is some hydrogen available to produce 1-octene. This eliminates possible substrate accumulation on the surface to form higher boiling products. In summary, the chemisorption studies and component miscibility tests further explain the relatively poor conversions obtained employing the SCILL systems, yet gave the necessary SCILL effect to selectively hydrogenate octyne and cause a gain in 1-octene in the product stream. IPA-TPD The acid site concentration of the fresh catalysts (5Ag/Al2O3 [20], 5Ag-10%[EIM], 5Ag-20%[BMIM][NTf2] and 5Ag-15%[BMIM][PF6]) was quantified using IPA-TPD measurements at low and moderate desorption temperatures as determined by the respective TGA-DSC profiles. This method analyses Brønsted acidity on surface sites by decomposition of isopropylamine into propylene and ammonia via the Hofmann elimination reaction [55–58]. The peak at 277 °C (Table 3 ) for the bare catalyst is assigned to chemisorbed propylene on the Brønsted acid sites [56,59–61], whilst the lower temperature peaks (observed as the main peak over the SCILLs) are assigned to propylene that is physisorbed or weakly held on the hydroxyl groups of alumina (Table 3, Fig. S10 in the Supplementary Information) [59,62]. The relative quantities of Brønsted acid sites detected for the bare, organic modified and SCILL systems decrease in the following order (Fig. S10, Supplementary Information): 5Ag/Al2O3 > 5Ag-10%[EIM] > 20%[BMIM][NTf2] > 5Ag-15%[BMIM][PF6] The concentration of the acid sites over all catalysts is generally low, ranging from 0.017 to 0.150 mmol/g (Table 3). This can imply that the effective acid site concentrations over the SCILLs are essentially similar, however, from Fig. S10 in the Supplementary Information, there is a clear decrease in acid site density due to the IL coating compared to the uncoated catalyst. For this reason, there is a noticeable reduction in isomeric olefin production over the SCILLs. Another observation is that the uncoated catalyst has two types of Brønsted acid sites, i.e. weak and medium sites, and upon coating only the weak acid site remains. Stronger acid sites generally increase the rate of side product formation. Hence, coating with the ionic liquid likely influenced the strength of the acid sites through coordination and minimised the extent at which isomer products were formed. A study by Li et al. [63] showed that alumina has a greater density of Lewis acid sites (0.34 mmol/g) than Brønsted acid sites (0.09 mmol/g), and few Brønsted acid sites are seen in the IPA-TPD results. In addition, it was previously noted that the uncoated 5Ag/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited good overall metal dispersion and the IL coating over these sites decreased the acid site density even further. The decrease in acidity across the SCILLs seemed to be dependent on both the cation and anion involved. An example of the ligand effect has been illustrated by Manrique et al. [64], noting that the coordination of phosphorus to the OH groups of alumina impeded the adsorption of pyridine (in pyridine TPD experiments) due to the decreased acid sites available. Similarly, the results of the IPA-TPD work in this study also suggest cationic and anionic interactions with the support surface as a result of coating with one monolayer. On the other hand, there are similar amounts of weak acid sites on the bare catalyst and the 5Ag-10%[EIM] catalyst. The absence of an anion in the organic modified catalyst would provide a greater amount of acid sites for side reactions to occur, and in this case, similar products as observed over the uncoated catalyst are expected, see Fig. 11 . The IPA-TPD data implies that in the 5Ag-10%[EIM] catalyst, EIM would orientate in a manner to give an “island-type” coverage on the catalyst surface, thus exposing more acid sites compared to the arrangements in the SCILLs, where the IL would possibly orientate in a side-side orientation, covering a larger surface area of acid sites. Isoconversion studies: cationic/anionic interactions The most commonly used ionic liquids are those bearing imidazolium ions mainly due their stability in oxidative and reductive environments and ease of preparation. At one monolayer coverage, the effect of the organic modifier, 1-ethylimidazole ([EIM]), and the chosen ILs with different anion sizes and electron donor strengths were screened for the SCILL effect. Comparisons were done at isoconversion (20% ± 2) to compare the selectivities of the unmodified 5Ag/Al2O3 and coated 5Ag/Al2O3 catalysts. From Fig. 11, a SCILL effect is demonstrated by all ionic liquids. The isoconversion study showed possible coordination between the soft acid (Ag) and each anion of the ionic liquids. Those which coordinated strongly, i.e. NTf2 − and PF6 − ions, gave low 1-octene gain due to active site poisoning, whilst higher gains were reached with the weaker coordinating, harder anions (BF4 − and NO3 −). With the unmodified catalyst, greater over-hydrogenation and isomerisation of 1-octene is seen since, in the initial stages of the reaction, the catalyst surface remains relatively “clean” [20]. Hence, the formed and readsorbed 1-octene can produce octane because there are no mass transfer limitations (later caused by deposition of carbonaceous layers) on the catalyst surface. It is also noted that there is a 1-octene gain over the [BMIM][NTf2], [BMIM][PF6], [BMIM][BF4], and [N4444][NO3] SCILLs as well as the organic modified catalyst. The highest 1-octene selectivity was recorded over 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] at 82%. There are some octene isomers present across the SCILLs and the organic modified catalyst, however, the largest content was noted over the unmodified 5Ag/Al2O3 catalyst. The trends in isomer formation have been previously explained in the IPA-TPD section of this report in terms of the exposed Brønsted acid sites on each catalyst. The previously observed sequence of available acidity (5Ag/Al2O3 > 5Ag-10%[EIM] > 20%[BMIM][NTf2] > 5Ag-15%[BMIM][PF6]) correlates well to the extent of octene isomers formed, where the largest content is noted for the unmodified and organic modified catalysts, whilst the least is observed over the 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] catalyst. The higher 1-octene selectivity over the ammonium-based SCILL compared to the imidazolium-based SCILLs is likely a result of the bulky and mildly coordinating IL, since coordination stems from the anion only, with the ammonium cation-metal interaction being weak due to ion repulsion. The weaker IL coordination further limits the possibility of poisoning the active sites and reducing the 1-octene gain as observed over the “softer” SCILLs. 1-Octene selectivities over the imidazolium-based catalysts are further affected by a Ag-imidazole ring interaction through the nitrogen lone pairs, apart from anion-metal interactions. For this reason, although active sites may be slowly poisoned by sulfur or phosphorus, the resulting π-donation from the nitrogen within the imidazolium functional group can also contribute electron density at the active sites which decreases the binding energy for substrates, aiding 1-octene desorption on those sites that remain active. In the case of [EIM], the absence of an anion show that support effects can also play a role in the reaction selectivity [65–67]. The basic component of the carrier can cause some decomposition of [EIM] and the decomposition products formed can combine with other polymeric species which usually form in greater quantity from exposed acidic alumina sites (“others”, Fig. 11). 3.3 Characterisation of used SCILLs 3.3.1 BET measurements Physisorption measurements (tabulated in Table 4 ) showed a decrease in BET surface area, pore volumes and pore sizes after coating [20] 5Ag/Al2O3 with the different ionic liquids. In general, a significant loss of the ionic liquid layer during the reaction can be ruled out as this would be evidenced by higher surfaces areas comparing post reaction catalysts to those of the fresh. A reduction in BET surface area from the freshly prepared bare catalyst to that of the used was attributed to the deposition of higher homologues of C8 within the pores and on the surface of the catalyst, previously proven by thermal analyses. All IL coated catalysts showed a surface area reduction after the reaction due to the deposition of organics. From Fig. S11(a) in the Supplementary Information, all catalysts exhibit Type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops. There are marked differences in the pore shapes of the used catalysts, as shown by the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms where the expected narrowing of isotherms is seen for the used catalysts as opposed to the fresh. Fig. S11(b, c) in the Supplementary Information shows the cumulative pore area and pore volume plotted against the average pore diameter and effectively shows changes to the pore network as the catalysts are coated by different ionic liquids to achieve a uniform monolayer. Reduced pore volumes and diameters post reaction imply that although each ionic liquid may be deposited into the catalyst pores during the initial coating, long reaction periods produce carbonaceous materials that are additionally deposited. According to Perdikaki et al., extreme narrowing of the pore openings in the SCILL systems limits gas diffusivities, and diffusion of the reactants and products into and out of pores may be classified as the rate determining step of the heterogeneous reaction [68]. Smaller pores are usually completely blocked [69]. The layer thickness, SIL, was calculated by taking the ratio of the IL volume used for coating and the initial surface area of the bare catalyst assuming a uniform distribution of the IL on the surface of the neat catalyst [70,71]. Table 5 shows that all catalysts achieved a layer thickness below 1 nm. Although this may imply incomplete coverage of the ionic liquid on the surface of the catalyst, TGA analyses of the used catalysts revealed a single peak indicative of the loss of the ionic liquid only, except for the ammonium-based ionic liquid. This showed losses of soft and hard coke at low and high temperatures, respectively, due to an incomplete or spatial distribution of this IL (Fig. S8, Supplementary Information). The pore filling degree, α, is a measure of the amount of ionic liquid occupying the pores. The lowest pore filling degree was calculated for the catalyst with the neutral organic modifier, 1-ethylimidazole, perhaps suggesting that most of it remains on the catalyst surface. 3.3.2 IR Representative IR data sets for all 5Ag/Al2O3 catalysts coated with the various ionic liquids as well as the organic modifier, [EIM], are shown in Table S2 (Supplementary Information). Molecular vibrations are illustrated in two different regions. Typically, the low frequency region represents fingerprints of mostly anions (1000–1600 cm−1), whilst the higher frequency region (2750–3250 cm−1) depicts the IR fingerprints of mainly cations [13,42]. In all cases of the IL coated catalysts (with IR experiments conducted at a resolution of 4 cm−1) cationic bands are very weak and are therefore unassigned (Figs. S13–S15, Supplementary Information), whilst anionic bands are intense in the fresh catalysts. In addition, the metal selection rule (MSR) states that only the component of the dipole perpendicular to the surface gives rise to the IR adsorption of the metal surface [72]. In this case, symmetric and antisymmetric modes of the anions are polarised perpendicular to the molecular axis and, therefore, the anions adopt a well-defined orientation with the molecular axis, perpendicular to the metal surface [15,72]. All ionic liquid samples illustrate an OH peak in the 3400–3800 cm−1 region (Figs. S12–S15, Supplementary Information). Typical IR bands lie in the range of 1100–1575 cm−1 for [EIM], whilst those for the anions [NTf2], [PF6], [BF4] and [NO3], are represented by 1380 cm−1, 558 cm−1, 987 cm−1, and 1756 cm−1, respectively. No cationic band shifts or changes in intensities were observed between the fresh and used catalysts. This was also observed for the [BMIM][NTf2] and [N4444][NO3] coated catalysts. This suggests little change in the local arrangement of these ILs under the reaction conditions. From Fig. S14 (Supplementary Information), the Al-O bands below 1000 cm−1 are prominent in the used [BMIM][PF6] SCILL but not in the case of the fresh. This result compliments the catalysis of the used [BMIM][PF6] catalyst, which shows increasing isomerisation products with time as a result of the exposed acidic alumina sites. 3.3.3 TGA-DSC Table 6 shows thermal analysis data for all fresh and used EIM and SCILL systems. Three of the four SCILLs showed the same mass loss for both fresh and used samples. This implies that the ionic liquids remained physisorbed through the reaction duration. Two distinct weight loss peaks were observed, i.e. weight losses associated with moisture during IL loading, and then the decomposition of the ionic liquid. It is generally expected that for supported ionic liquids, the Td (IL decomposition temperature) shifts to lower temperatures from those observed for the bulk IL due to support effects [49,67,73]. It has been reported that this usually occurs when the support catalyses the decomposition of the supported ionic liquid at lower temperatures than the thermal stability of the bulk IL and this is controlled by the surface acidity of the support [13,48,65]. This is not the case with all SCILLs in this study, since for the used 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3], there are multiple mass losses occurring after 200 °C (Fig. S8, Supplementary Information). The close proximity of the large cation and carrier could have initiated the decomposition reaction leading to fragmentation of the IL. In general, the T onset – T end and Td data show that the ILs used to coat the Ag have high thermal stability limits and thus prove that the reaction conditions used (140 °C) should cause minimal IL decomposition. 3.3.4 HR-TEM HR-TEM analyses and line scan measurements by STEM were performed on selected used catalysts. The BSE image (Fig. 12 (a)) of the used 5Ag-10%[BMIM][PF6] catalyst shows dense areas of bright spots due to silver enrichment on the surface of alumina. Line scans in Fig. 12(b–g) reveal intactness of the ionic liquid after the 72 h time-on-stream. This is indicative of minimal or no ionic liquid leaching occurring. This result was further confirmed by thermal analysis showing a mass loss of the original amount of IL loaded (Fig. S8, Supplementary Information). STEM-EDX analyses of the used nitrogen-containing catalysts (5Ag-10%[EIM] and 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3]) are reported in the Supplementary Information (Figs. S16,S17) and also lend evidence to the continued presence of the organic modifier and [N4444][NO3] IL after the respective time-on-stream studies. Previously, XRD results revealed high peak intensities of the active metal, and this was attributed to the weakening of the metal-support interaction caused by the ionic liquid. Interestingly, Fig. 12(a–g) and Fig. 13 (a–g) display a noticeable increase in the detection of the P and F and B and F, respectively, in the regions of increased silver enrichment. The relationship between these elements and silver shows that a dominant interaction still exists between the metal and ionic liquid, confirming the aforementioned argument. TEM images (Fig. 14 ) suggested that some nanoparicles seen in the fresh uncoated catalysts formed larger agglomerates upon coating, with some particles showing chain-like structures (Fig. S18, Supplementary Information). A similar trend was noticed between the fresh and used SCILLs as well as the organic modified catalyst (Fig. 14(a–d)). A thorough measurement of the particle sizes (100 particles) gave diameters of 42 nm, 45 nm, 39 nm and 39 nm for the used 5Ag-10%[EIM], 5Ag-15%[BMIM]PF6], 5Ag-15%[BMIM]BF4] and 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] catalysts, respectively, compared to their initial fresh catalyst sizes of 33 nm, 43 nm, 23 nm and 36 nm, respectively. Spherical particle shapes were assumed for the particle size analysis. Wide particle size distributions were revealed for all used catalysts as seen in Fig. 14(e–h). Silver is generally regarded as a mobile metal and hence long reaction periods promote sintering of the metal causing larger agglomerates of silver being distributed on the surface of alumina. The particle size distributions imply that a sintering mechanism also contributed to a loss in activity of all catalysts, seen from their respective time-on-stream studies. It is well documented that catalyst activity can be correlated to the sizes of metal particles [74]. Smaller particles generally offer high metallic surface areas than do larger particles. Alkynes generally adsorb and hydrogenate on both flat and terrace surfaces (low-coordination sites) with alkenes reacting faster on flat sites as a result of steric hindrance of adsorption on terraces. With a low concentration of these low-coordination sites, reactant adsorption is usually diminished, hence decreasing activities are noticed with time as seen with these catalysts. 4 Summary and conclusion Investigation into the effect of different ionic liquids with common cations and different anions showed a clear SCILL effect where the selectivity towards 1-octene was enhanced through established ligand-like effects and mass transfer effects where these were due to IL surface arrangements and the packing efficiency as well as the bulkiness of the IL. The near surface arrangement was confirmed to be a side-side orientation of ions according to XPS analyses. Component miscibility tests showed low miscibility of all components within the individual ionic liquids ruling out selectivity changes caused by physical solvent effects of the IL. The effect of different [BMIM][NTf2] loadings confirmed that 20% IL was sufficient to enhance the selectivity towards 1-octene and increase the octene content in a feed initially consisting of 10% octene and 2% octyne in hexane. A LHSV of 9 h−1 was shown to enhance the interaction between the substrates and the metal phase aiding easier diffusion through the IL layer thus increasing the conversion of 1-octyne. Time-on-stream studies revealed that the [BMIM][PF6] coated catalyst almost completely deactivates with a conversion of 2% at the end of 72 h. With [BMIM][BF4] and [N4444][NO3], with lower coordinating potential, increased conversions were noted in their time-on-stream studies. Isoconversion of 1-octyne at 20% showed an increased gain of 1-octene from the organic modified catalyst to the IL modified catalysts. The highest selectivity to 1-octene (the product resulting from the hydrogenation of octyne using the competitive feed) was recorded over the 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] catalyst at 82%. The S- and P- containing ionic liquids poisoned the active sites of the catalyst causing severe catalyst deactivation. Comparisons of the IL modified catalysts with the organic modified catalyst revealed possible coordination of the cation, [BMIM]+, with the metal. Preliminary studies using a feed containing 1-octyne only gave 100% 1-octyne conversion with a selectivity of 100% towards 1-octene over 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3]. With a feed containing 1-octene only, low conversions were noted over the bare, organic modified, 5Ag-20%[BMIM][NTf2] and 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] catalysts. TG analyses of all used SCILLs revealed no IL leaching occurring except for the ammonium-based SCILL system. Notable, the organic modified EIM catalyst showed leaching. ICP-OES suggested slight leaching of the metal, whilst HR-TEM studies showed agglomeration of particles due to metal sintering. These findings were associated to the decline in 1-octyne conversion in the time-on-stream studies. Despite surface coverage by the ILs, N2 physisorption measurements showed high surface areas in the fresh catalysts which decreased in the used SCILLs due to deposition of a small amount of organic material on the surface of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of 1-octyne (in 1-octene) to 1-octene was carried out over a 5Ag/Al2O3 catalyst coated at one monolayer (ML) coverage with 20 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][NTf2]) as the first model system, followed by coating with 15 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([BMIM][PF6]), 15 wt% 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([BMIM][BF4]), 15 wt% tetrabutylammonium nitrate ([N4444][NO3]) and the equivalent organic modifier, 1-ethylimidazole [EIM] (10 wt%). The initial uncoated catalyst gave high octyne conversions (99%) with a selectivity to 1-octene at 30% initially, reaching 70% within 24 h on-stream. In an attempt to improve the selectivity and catalyst stability with time, modifying the catalyst with [EIM] gave 1-octene selectivities of 50% over 36 h time-on-stream with an average 1-octene gain of 10 wt%. The conversion of 1-octyne decreased significantly from 99% over the uncoated catalyst to 30% over the modified version as a result of diffusion limitations. However, coating with different ionic liquids ([BMIM][NTf2], [BMIM][PF6], [BMIM][BF4] and [N4444][NO3]) gave increased 1-octene selectivities reaching up to 82% over the 5Ag-15%[N4444][NO3] catalyst. The stability of most SCILLs was maintained for a period exceeding 10 h after which deactivation of the active catalytic sites by either poisoning or metal sintering led to a decline in activity.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of organic modifiers on Ag/Al2O3 catalysts for the sequential hydrogenation of 1-octyne vs 1-octene
